title._content: [Portrait of Edwin A. Finckel in his home, Greenwich Village, New York, N.Y., ca. Nov. 1946] (LOC)

description._content: Gottlieb, William P., 1917-, photographer. [Portrait of Edwin A. Finckel in his home, Greenwich Village, New York, N.Y., ca. Nov. 1946] 1 negative : b&w ; 2 1/4 x 2 1/4 in. Caption from Down Beat: Currently arranging (and generally running the music end) for the Buddy Rich orchestra, Eddie is the ex-Washington arranger who wrote and scored "Boyd Meets Stravinsky" and other revolutionary items for which Boyd Raeburn and Geoge Handy are generally credited. Eddie and his wife, Helen (altoist Harry Klee's sister), live in one of those mad Greenwich Village apartments you read about but seldom see. It has red ceilings, a stairway in the middle of the studio and a two-tier breakfast room. Among the more-or-less permanent furnishings are paintings by Finckel, including the impaled hands in the photo, and Alec Wilder, who has a bed there for resting between wild flights of music writing. Notes: Gottlieb Collection Assignment No. 508 Reference print available in Music Division, Library of Congress. Purchase William P. Gottlieb Forms part of: William P. Gottlieb Collection (Library of Congress). In: The Record Changer, v. 5, no. 9 (Nov. 46, 1946), p. 13. Subjects: Finckel, Edwin A. Jazz musicians--1940-1950. Format: Portrait photographs--1940-1950. Film negatives--1940-1950. Rights Info: Mr. Gottlieb has dedicated these works to the public domain, but rights of privacy and publicity may apply. lcweb2.loc.gov/diglib/ihas/html/gottlieb/gottlieb-copyrig...
